claim_ui_checks.claim: The current system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days, requiring manual tracking and interventions for overtime and unpaid leaves.

checks.name: semantic_payroll_calculation_automation_gap
checks.claim_text: The current system lacks automated salary calculation based on precise working days, requiring manual tracking and interventions for overtime and unpaid leaves.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_formula_override
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator in payroll settings intentionally overrides the leave policy formula for unpaid leave. The leave policy formula appears greyed out, indicating it is not active. This creates user confusion about which formula is actually being applied for daily wage calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_calculation
checks.claim_text: System failed to recalculate pending unpaid leave deductions when new salary configurations were created after leave request submission. Deductions were incorrectly based on previous salary configuration instead of current one, resulting in payroll calculation discrepancies.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for leap years (specifically 2024), resulting in an inaccurate total service period and reduced gratuity amount.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_calculation_error
checks.claim_text: The system incorrectly calculates service days by using 365 days instead of 366 days for leap years (specifically 2024), resulting in an inaccurate total service period and reduced gratuity amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

checks.name: semantic_eos_calculation_decimal_precision
checks.claim_text: End of Service (EOS) calculation is producing incorrect pro-rated amounts due to a rounding or decimal precision error. The daily wage formula (basic + allowances / 30) is configured correctly, but when calculating pro-rated EOS amounts, the system consistently shows amounts that are less than expected by 0.1 or 0.2 decimals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System gratuity calculation shows slight differences from manual calculations due to complex service duration and daily wage formula

checks.name: semantic_gratuity_calculation_complexity
checks.claim_text: System gratuity calculation shows slight differences from manual calculations due to complex service duration and daily wage formula

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (specifically February 29th), potentially causing minor discrepancies in service duration calculations. The system calculated 912 days, while manual calculation suggested 913 days including the leap day.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_calculation
checks.claim_text: The system's gratuity calculation may not consistently handle leap year days (specifically February 29th), potentially causing minor discrepancies in service duration calculations. The system calculated 912 days, while manual calculation suggested 913 days including the leap day.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System calculates one extra day in job tenure (622 vs 623 days), potentially affecting gratuity calculation precision. The platform captures 623 days instead of the expected 622 days when computing years of service.

checks.name: semantic_gratuity_calculation_days_discrepancy
checks.claim_text: System calculates one extra day in job tenure (622 vs 623 days), potentially affecting gratuity calculation precision. The platform captures 623 days instead of the expected 622 days when computing years of service.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. Users may misunderstand how daily wage is divided (31 vs 30 days) and resulting prorated salary amount.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_policy
checks.claim_text: System calculates leave salary based on predefined policy configuration, which may not align with user expectations about calendar days and prorated calculations. Users may misunderstand how daily wage is divided (31 vs 30 days) and resulting prorated salary amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_accrual_variation
checks.claim_text: The daily wage calculator's 'working days' setting causes monthly fluctuations in leave salary accrual calculations. The daily wage rate changes based on the number of working days in each month, leading to inconsistent cumulative totals.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system uses different divisors for leave salary and salary proration calculations. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor, while salary proration uses a 30.42-day divisor, causing calculation discrepancies.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_divisor_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system uses different divisors for leave salary and salary proration calculations. Leave salary uses a 30-day divisor, while salary proration uses a 30.42-day divisor, causing calculation discrepancies.

claim_ui_checks.claim: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation_misunderstanding
checks.claim_text: User initially misunderstood how working days are calculated based on work week configuration. The system was actually calculating correctly, but the user did not initially understand that their specific work week (NVK Operations) had all 7 days configured as working days.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When processing payroll earlier than the departure date, the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

checks.name: semantic_salary_proration_future_departure
checks.claim_text: The system fails to correctly prorate salaries when an employee's departure date is in the future relative to payroll processing date. When processing payroll earlier than the departure date, the system displays the full monthly salary instead of a prorated amount.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_deduction_sync
checks.claim_text: When an unpaid leave request is approved and transaction submitted, then the daily wage calculation is changed and the transaction deleted to recalculate, the system creates duplicate deductions—one with the old calculation and one with the new. Deleting the leave request does not remove associated payroll deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, there is a timing mismatch between Payroll and Time Off modules causing incorrect daily wage calculations. The system cannot recalculate deductions retroactively, leading to inconsistent salary deduction amounts.

checks.name: semantic_public_holiday_calculation_mismatch
checks.claim_text: When public holidays are added after a leave request is created, there is a timing mismatch between Payroll and Time Off modules causing incorrect daily wage calculations. The system cannot recalculate deductions retroactively, leading to inconsistent salary deduction amounts.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system displays incorrect number of days (31 instead of 29) in the remarks section for February unpaid leave calculations, despite the backend calculation being mathematically correct.

checks.name: semantic_remarks_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system displays incorrect number of days (31 instead of 29) in the remarks section for February unpaid leave calculations, despite the backend calculation being mathematically correct.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave deductions. Instead of using Basic Salary / Working Days as configured, the system uses a global daily rate that calculates deductions using gross salary, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

checks.name: semantic_unpaid_leave_calculation_override
checks.claim_text: The system applies a global daily rate configuration that overrides individual leave policy settings for unpaid leave deductions. Instead of using Basic Salary / Working Days as configured, the system uses a global daily rate that calculates deductions using gross salary, potentially leading to incorrect salary deductions.

claim_ui_checks.claim: The system recalculates daily rates based on the payroll processing month instead of storing and displaying the rate from the original leave occurrence month, causing user confusion.

checks.name: semantic_daily_rate_display_mismatch
checks.claim_text: The system recalculates daily rates based on the payroll processing month instead of storing and displaying the rate from the original leave occurrence month, causing user confusion.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month, calculated from 365 annual days minus 52 weekly offs, resulting in 313 working days per year divided by 12 months.

checks.name: semantic_working_days_calculation
checks.claim_text: Salary is based on a standard 26 working days per month, calculated from 365 annual days minus 52 weekly offs, resulting in 313 working days per year divided by 12 months.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Payroll daily wage calculator configuration overrides leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations. The payroll-side configuration always takes precedence.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_formula_precedence
checks.claim_text: Payroll daily wage calculator configuration overrides leave policy formula for unpaid leave calculations. The payroll-side configuration always takes precedence.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Unpaid leave deduction calculations are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.

checks.name: semantic_salary_configuration_timing
checks.claim_text: Unpaid leave deduction calculations are dependent on the timing of salary configuration creation relative to leave request submission.

claim_ui_checks.claim: System defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize 366 days in leap years during service period calculations.

checks.name: semantic_leap_year_day_count_limitation
checks.claim_text: System defaults to 365 days per year, failing to recognize 366 days in leap years during service period calculations.

claim_ui_checks.claim: Daily wage calculations consistently produce amounts that are 0.1 or 0.2 less than expected when computing pro-rated End of Service amounts.

checks.name: semantic_daily_wage_calculation_precision
checks.claim_text: Daily wage calculations consistently produce amounts that are 0.1 or 0.2 less than expected when computing pro-rated End of Service amounts.

checks.name: semantic_monthly_leave_accrual_policy
checks.claim_text: Leave days are only accrued at the end of the month, preventing prorated accrual for mid-month departures
